item.text: From my very brief knowledge of Wikispaces Classroom,
In my very cursory knowledge of Wikispaces Classroom, the two advantages of FedWiki that jump to mind are:

1) Ability for students to (potentially) retain ownership of their contributions. In many cases, the wiki would still be hosted for the student by the instructor or university -- but the potential is there to at least discuss the concept of data ownership in this context.
2) In Federated Wiki, [[we make the road by walking]].
2) In Federated Wiki, [[we make the road by walking]], where as in Wikispaces Classroom, the box is prefabricated and the users are dropped in.

In the name of fairness, I'd imagine that Wikispaces is easier to get up and running, and probably to grade/evaluate student contributions -- but those strike me as minor points compared to the FedWiki advantages above.
